instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi.

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has 20V from ampmeter, but 0A.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> seams to be shorted, but I can't see nothing hot (injected 1.5V).

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 0V
Diode reading on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.002

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check (ohm scale) if you get same reading on any big coil.
Use 10-20A PSU, setting amp limit to max first.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I don't have a 10A PSU. But with my 5A PSU it only gets around 2A of consume with 1.5V injected

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Did you set amp limit to max?
Even 3W should heat something on the board.
Use powerful cables; your interest is not heating the cables.
An IR cam may help you to find the culprit.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi,
Yes, I set the amp limit to max (5A), and I already use the thermal cam, but I can't see nothing hot.

With the amp limit to 5A, injecting 1.5V, only consumes around 2A. 

Shall I increase the voltage*?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Be sure first the short doesn't come from a secondary coil!!!
